ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Overview of multivariable calculus.
Multivariable calculus.
Preparing and learning all material before class, time management, and the importance of reaching out to TAs, peer tutors, and professors.
I learned a lot about higher variable functions and integrals in 2D/3D space.
I learned multivarible calculus
I developed a strong understanding of vectors in 3D space and multivariate calculus.
problem solving, breaking a problem down, how to apply integration and differentiation to multiple variables
I learned the basics of multi-variable calculus; the first portion of the class was focused on derivatives, and the second portion was focused on integrals.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: - very organized. but exams havve too much weight, which causes stress on students.

Strengths: course material was well-structured; the "flipped classroom" model worked well.

Weaknesses: pace of the course was incredibly fast, and at times, didn't really have time to absorb the material before having to jump into new content; exams were on the more difficult side, and the grading scheme of no curve on exams made it difficult.

It definetely was challenging to be expected to watch an hour worth of lecture videos before each class in addition to homework. It was also very frustrating when that same material is what would be taught in class making the pre-lecture videos essentially pointless but still mandatory. I like the amount of collaborative practice problems we did in class, and it was nice to have small sections. I think the psets were just the right level of challenging.

There were resources provided in this class, not as much as for Math 115, but there was a good network of peer tutors. Also, learning material from online videos before class, though difficult and long in the moment, helped to learn the material better than a professor would under a time crunch, which allowed for the preparation of specific questions. However, there was a lot of the material was difficult and extensive (students need to be prepared for extensive work on problem sets and review of class material on a regular basis).
I think that a day of review before each exam would have been helpful to iron out any confusion in classes.

The bureaucracy of this course is terrible. It felt like everyone was working against me instead of with me in a lot of regards, even though my individual instructor was fine. The math department needs to get with the times and try and help students, especially those who are a) not math majors and b) not people with strong math backgrounds.
It was very interesting but way too fast
The course has a lot of content and materials that help you review, though the sections themselves do not add much to the content that is already covered in the pre-recorded videos.

weaknesses- instructors not that great. basically self taught

strengths- resources to teach ur self are good. highly recommend using peer tutors and ximera

Strength: many resources! PSETS, the class Ximera site, and practice exams were all great ways to access practice questions to help prepare for exams.

Weaknesses: 85% of your grade is made up of your 3 exam scores, which puts a disproportionate amount of pressure on those days as opposed to the homework assignments and pre-quizzes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It's a great overview of multivariable calculus, and whether you're taking it for your major or just out of interest, there's a lot to be gained. Preparing for the course beforehand will probably allow you to perform your best, as well as staying on top of everything each week during the semester. It can be a lot of work!
I would probably suggest they take ENAS 151 if possible because I have heard better things about it.
I would recommend this course if it is a major requirement or the student has a particular interest in the field and looking for great academic challenge.

I would recommend this course but only with a certain professor. Some professors were great at explaining content and others were not as committed to the class and it showed. I think that there was a huge disparity in performance just based on professors which is unfortunately something the students cannot control.
Only if they have to.
Yes because it gives you the basis of a lot of future math at Yale
If you are interested in calculus or want to take higher level courses in statistics, economics, or math, this is an important course to take.
yea, if you have to. you learn a lot.

If you need this course for your major or think you might be interested in math at Yale, then yes! If not, it may not be for you, since the material is almost entirely out-of-context calculus problems, rather than material that explores calculus applications in other fields. Additionally, I would advise anyone considering this course to think about their own calculus experience  this class is a lot of work, and while there are many helpful resources, the need to individually review foundational material might set you a bit behind.
